Replying to @americanwombat 2018-12-13 23:00
@americanwombat @Netlify Sounds to me like you'd like to refresh a browser session after it has loaded if a new version is deployed during that session. That's *very* edge case. Each Netlify deploy purges the cache so that each visit will get the latest version. Users would get latest when nagivating too

Replying to @philhawksworth 2018-12-12 12:12
@mr_mading @Netlify Also... if you enabled Netlify DNS for that domain, Netlify will no longer have the entries for incoming DNS. You'll want to remove the DNS zone for that domain (via https://t.co/CSEdzrn1w9) to get back to not using Netlify's DNS management.

Replying to @ensina 2018-12-11 18:09
@ensina @NetlifySupport @Netlify Hey Sina, Keep in mind that this hosting is for JAMstack (or pre-rendered) sites. So there is no server running at request time in which to run a PostgresSQL DB. You could perhaps use this via #serverless functions as part of a decoupled API architecture.

Replying to @CarlRosell 2018-12-06 23:44
@CarlRosell @kentcdodds @Netlify @airtable Ha ha! I know the feeling. I made a tool to generate that _redirects file based on the urls posted to @Netlify's forms API. Replying to @AndyWhalePhoto 2018-12-06 11:00
@AndyWhalePhoto @frontendyork @imconnorm @AndyCallaghan @Netlify Yep. I like to think about putting as much distance as possible between the users, and the complexity.
